%text If the set of \underline\text{all possible events}$(S)$ be divided into smaller sets $E_1, E_2, \ldots$ such that
% \begin{tabular}{|c|l|} \hline \text{Condition} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline E_i\cap E_j = \phi\,(i\neq j) & \text{$E_i$ and $E_j$ are mutually} \\ &\text{exclusive for any $i$ and $j$} \\ \hline E_i\cup E_j\cup\ldots E_n = S & \text{$E_i\ldots E_n$ are exhaustive} \\ \hline E_i \neq \phi\text{ for any $i$} & \text{All $E_i$ have non-zero size} \\ \hline \end{tabular} %text
then an event $A$ will intersect with \underline\text{some or all} of $E_1, E_2,\ldots E_n$. And hence, the probability of $A$ occurring can \underline\text{also be expressed} as
\[ \qquad P(A) = \sum_{i=1}^n P(E_i)\cdot P\left( A\,\vert\, E_i\right)\] %
